Award.AwardTitle: iNeuro: Response to an identified need for a workforce trained to curate and manage large scale data and databases

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The potential for advances in coordinated design, production and analysis of big-data bases in neuroscience to help us better understand the interaction between the structure and function of the brain are highlighted by the White House Brain Initiative (http://whitehouse.gov/share/brain-initiative). However, in order for that potential to be realized, there is a need for a workforce capable of both creating and maintaining these data bases in a sustainable, well annotated, easily accessible format. This workshop is designed to consider the challenges inherent in educating such a work force and ensuring undergraduate education in information-neuroscience (iNeuro) will reflect the diversity of the nation's population and institutions of higher education, consider the myriad demands on that work force, and promote workforce flexibility in responding to changing needs and resources as the discipline evolves. It will benefit the nation in such areas as workforce development, curriculum enrichment, undergraduate student education and establishing interdisciplinary approaches to complex national challenges.

This one and one-half day iNeuro workshop will create a roadmap outlining necessary steps to educate the next generation of information curators/scientists. It will identify: 1) the skill set(s) and training necessary for such individuals (e.g. neuroscience, mathematics and quantitative methods, information science, computer science, and others) as well as the appropriate trans-disciplinary blend, 2) the educators and programs needed to train such individuals, and (3) actions needed to help faculty and institutions incorporate the precepts advanced by the Vision and Change report into their educational strategies/programs. Attendees will represent the full spectrum of higher education institutions across the nation and will include experts in such areas as: managers and purveyors of data resources, individuals involved in bioinformatics/analytics training, library and information scientists, computer scientists, neuroscience educators and research-involved neuroscientists. The workshop will be preceded by a period of information exchange among the participants to ensure an efficient use of workshop time and will be followed by production of a white paper summarizing workshop findings.

This project is being supported jointly by the Division of Undergraduate Education and the Division of Research on Learning in the Directorate of Education and Human Resources and the Division of Biological Infrastructure and the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems within the Directorate of Biological Sciences as part of their efforts toward support of Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of this project stems from the iNeuro Workshop held November 13–14, 2014, in Arlington, VA, to determine the human capital needs created by the impending era of Big Data in neuroscience. The workshop participants consisted of individuals with multiple perspectives on the problem including data resource providers, bioinformatics/analytics trainers, computer scientists, library scientists, neuroscience educators, and NSF program officers as observers. These participants were charged with answering the following questions: (1) What skill sets does a scientist/curator of Big Data in neuroscience need? (2) What degree level(s) will be necessary for these individuals to attain the proper training? (3) What curriculum will be required to build the desired skill sets?  (4) What programs exist, and could they serve as models for new ones? (5) Can the recommendations for transforming lifesciences education provided in Vision and Change be utilized to inform both the curricula and the mode of delivery when instructing students in using Big Data in neuroscience?

Participants envisioned three levels of employees in this emerging field: (1) data researcher or computational neuroinformatician/modeler; (2) a data steward; and (3) data technician/manager/advocate. Regardless of the position level, workshop participants expected that this workforce would need specific skills, knowledge, and competencies in the following domains: (a) research; (b) computational; (c) strategic; and (d) relational (communication, collaboration, and ethics). Participants felt that these positions would require graduate training but that undergraduate programs could be instituted that would prepare students for subsequent graduate training. Participants were fairly unified about curricula for training a Ph.D. data researcher or computational neuroinformatician/modeler. Participants had diverse suggestions for training the other positions at the Master’s level (details on curricula can be found in the iNeuro Project Workshop Report—see URL at end). Regardless, participants advocated curricular approaches consistent with Vision and Change (http://visionandchange.org/files/2013/11/aaas-VISchange-web1113.pdf)--integrating authentic research experiences into educational programs such as a capstone experience tackling a real-world, Big Data neuroscience problem. Participants did not know of any concerted neuroinformatics programs in the USA but mentioned some in Europe. Means of formulating programs were discussed, and the easiest means seemed to be to piece together elements of existing programs within an institution, particularly if there were already programs in such fields as database administration, bioinformatics/computational biology, neuroscience, and information studies. Proposed training programs will create curricular demands that will require faculty development as well as institutional resources. Regardless, workshop participants all agreed that there was an urgent need to train a workforce with the skills required to handle Big Data in neuroscience in order to capture the promise that Big Data holds.

The project included a large dissemination effort in order for the ideas generated by the workshop to have broader impacts. This included not only writing the iNeuro Project Workshop Report and making it available online but also three other articles. One of these articles encapsulates the discussions of the workshop and is available online in an open-access journal, Frontiers in Neuroinformatics: doi: 10.3389/fninf.2016.00028 .  Another article will soon be available from another open-access site, the Journal of Undergraduate Neuroscience Education http://www.funjournal.org/. Dissemination efforts also included five abstracts and presentations at such venues as the AAAS/NSF symposium, “Envisioning the Future of Undergraduate STEM Education (EnFUSE): Research and Practice” April 27-29, 2016, the Faculty for Undergraduate Neuroscience 2017 Workshop, the Society for Neuroscience annual meeting, and the American Society for Cell Biology annual meeting. Presentations were also made at the University of Miami and the Teaching and Education Committee of the International Neuroinformatics Coordinating Facility. Copies of the White paper were given to the TEC of INCF as well as emailed to the Neuroscience Training Committee of the Society for Neuroscience. Copies were also distributed and emailed to administrators, faculty, and policy makers who could inaugurate the teaching efforts proposed.

 The full report of the iNeuro Workshop report is available in a White Paper at the following URL:

https://mdcune.psych.ucla.edu/ineuro/reports/iNeuro_WorkshopReport_v20170123.pdf)
